Public? --> | foundation = 2008 <!-- year --> | company_slogan = | location = [[Pasadena, California]] | key_people = [[Tim Cadogan]] (CEO), [[Jonathan Miller]] (Chairman) | industry = [[Online Advertising]], [[SaaS]], [[Big Data]] | products = [[Ad serving]], [[Ad exchange]], [[Yield Management]] | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | num_employees = 250<ref name="lat" /> | homepage = {{official website|http://www.openx.com/}} | intl = }} '''OpenX''' is a leading provider of digital and mobile advertising technology, enabling businesses to manage and maximize their ad revenue. The company, founded in 2008, has raised over $70 million from venture capitalists in five rounds.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/technology/2011/05/openx-venture-capital-profit.html |title=OpenX, Web ad firm, raises $20 million, expects to be profitable within a year |author=David Sarno |date=2011-05-31 |publisher=Los Angeles Times |accessdate=May 31, 2011}}</ref>
OpenX revenue management products include OpenX Enterprise, OpenX Market and OpenX Lift. It is the industry's first fully integrated Software-as-a-Service platform that combines ad serving, ad exchange and yield optimization.
Key Metrics Include: * OpenX served more than 1 trillion ad impressions in 2011
* OpenX Enterprise used by over 5000 publishers globally
* OpenX Market used by 95% of leading national advertisers and 41% of comScore 500 publishers
* OpenX operates five data centers in the U.S., Europe and Asia<ref>http://www.openx.com/about/facts</ref>
The company was formerly known as Openads and was founded in the [[United Kingdom]].<ref name="tele" /> Former AOL CEO [[Jonathan Miller]] is the Chairman, and [[Tim Cadogan]] from Yahoo is the CEO.
In February 2011, the company announced OpenX Enterprise also powers deals for [[Groupon]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://venturebeat.com/2011/02/08/openx-enterprise-groupon/|title=OpenX upgrades ad technology, Groupon signs on|last=Ha|first=Anthony|date=8 February 2011|work=[[VentureBeat]]|accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.forbes.com/2010/03/30/google-doubleclick-yahoo-rightmedia-ad-exchanges-microsoft-cmo-network-openx-orange.html|title=Provoking Google And Yahoo|last=Burkitt|first=Laurie|date=31 March 2010|work=[[Forbes]]|accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref> has a partnership with [[Dentsu]], and serves ads for [[Huffington Post]], [[Match.com]], [[Publicis]], [[WPP plc]], and [[Scholastic Corporation]].<ref name="tele">{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/yourbusiness/8542765/OpenX-raises-20m-as-it-signals-new-era-for-online-advertising.html|title=OpenX raises $20m as it signals new era for online advertising|last=Tyler|first=Richard|date=31 May 2011|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref>
The company's second round of [[venture capital]] funding was led by [[Accel Partners]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.openx.org/about/pressreleases/openads_series_b_funding|title=Openads Closes $15.5 Million Series B Funding Led By Accel Partners|date=16 January 2008|accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref> In May 2009, OpenX raised $10 million in third-round funding from [[DAG Ventures]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.marketingpilgrim.com/2009/05/openx-raises-another-10m-to-help-in-its-efforts-to-bring-down-google.html|title=OpenX Raises Another $10M to Help in Its Efforts to Bring Down Google|last=Beal|first=Andy|date=26 May 2009|work=Marketing Pilgrim|accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.siliconbeat.com/2009/05/26/openx-expands-war-chest-to-compete-with-google-and-yahoo/|title=OpenX expands war chest to compete with Google and Yahoo|last=Ackerman|first=Elise|date=26 May 2009|work=[[SiliconBeat]]|accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref> In May 2011, OpenX announced a fourth round of funding, $20 million, led by [[SAP Ventures]], as well as [[AOL Ventures]], [[Mitsui & Co.]] Global Investment, and [[Presidio Ventures]], as well as previous investors.<ref name="lat">{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/technology/2011/05/openx-venture-capital-profit.html|title=OpenX, Web ad firm, raises $20 million, expects to be profitable within a year|last=Sarno|first=David|date=31 May 2011|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://finance.fortune.cnn.com/2011/05/31/venture-capital-deals-3/|title=Venture Capital Deals - The Term Sheet: Fortune's deals blog Term Sheet|last=Primack|first=Dan|date=31 May 2011|work=[[CNN]]|accessdate=31 May 2011}}</ref>
OpenX competes with [[AppNexus]], Google's [[DoubleClick]]/[[Ad Manager]], and Yahoo!'s [[Right Media]].<ref name="tele" />
In February 2012, OpenX acquired LiftDNA (OpenX Lift), a next generation SSP for 'tens of millions'.<ref>http://blogs.wsj.com/venturecapital/2012/02/27/the-daily-start-up-openx-buys-liftdna-in-digital-ad-deal/</ref> In October 2012, OpenX acquired content valuation company Jumptime.<ref>http://www.openx.com/content/openx-acquires-pioneering-content-valuation-company-jumptime</ref>
In January 2013, OpenX raised $22.5 million in a round led by strategic partner, Samsung. OpenX technology powers Samsung AdHub where advertisers can buy ad impressions in real time across all Samsung devices including mobile, tablet and TV.
In July 2013, net-security.org posted an article concerning "Serious vulnerabilities in OpenX ad platform expose millions to risk": http://www.net-security.org/secworld.php?id=15179
